ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Understand computer networks in general. Distributed algorithm (distance vector routing), implemented a TCP protocol.
An overview of networking principles and protocols, and a broader understanding of how complex systems are engineered.
Computer network structure, system design, Internet protocols (http, tcp, udp, ip, ethernet)
Learned a lot about switching, computing system layers, different procedures within computer networks, etc.
We learned about computer networks and various network protocols for different layers of the internet.
networks, how to design and implement distributed systems
Knowledge of all of the layers of the internet and how they fit together.
We reviewed a number of network protocols and principles. The course was very comprehensive and I have emerged with an understanding of how the Internet works.

An understanding of the concepts underlying the different layers in computer networks, with a focus on the internet. I understand commonplace networking terms like TCP, IP, HTTP, Ethernet, DHCP and DNS better, and have better insight into why these things are designed the way they are.
Knowledge about history, state, and future of networking. How routers work, and how the internet today functions. We actually learned a great deal in this class!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I think the course is very good. Anurag is an amazing professor and is very clear in instruction. He is able to break down concepts nicely and his slides are very clear. There are a lot of strengths.
After the exams, I feel that one weakness is that sometimes, lectures do not capture more tricky details of the concepts introduced, at least I didn't grasp them fully by watching the lecture at one go. I think maybe Anurag can provide more examples showing some edge cases regarding understanding the concepts.
This is a minor weakness and the class is excellent.

Strengths: Anurag is a fantastic lecturer who cares a lot about his students and the class. You will learn a lot by paying attention in lecture and asking questions.

Weaknesses: Some of the homework assignments were a little tedious and underspecified, and some rough edges on the projects which will hopefully be ironed out in future iterations of the course.
Interesting course material. Professor is good at lecturing about general concepts. Sometimes topics were confusing, but could be clarified through piazza/office hours.

I thought this was a fantastic course, I would say that maybe if there were more homeworks but of shorter length that would be great, because sometimes it felt like it would be a while before we would have a place to review/apply our learning.

Strengths: nice slides, the course has great coverage and applicability in the real world
Weaknesses: very hard class with super long exams
The lecture is great and the course is taught in a very logical way that makes it easy to understand the very complex multi-layered internet that we rely on today.

The workload was incredibly manageable and all the assignments were designed to allow for an in-depth understanding of the material. The purpose is not to overwhelm but ensure that you are following what's going on in class.

I think Anurag's lectures are fantastic and the class participation element makes them more engaging than the average CS class. The Psets are well designed and help you come to grips with the material better.

If I had to nitpick about weaknesses, I would have preferred that the 2nd exam be held during finals week instead of being rushed right after the last Pset was due. The 2 projects were fun, but it would be nice if we dealt with the actual sockets and ports, etc. ourselves instead of only implementing the higher level features.

The strength: Anurag is a great lecturer, Projects (programming assignments) were pretty interesting and not excessive in number (We only had 3), and homework assignments were pretty tricky but critical to understanding the class.

Con: sometimes Anurag goes too fast and the lecture can seem very dense, so ask questions to stop him and ask him to explain things!
Great slides and highly knowledgeable professor

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think asking questions in lectures is helpful in staying virtually engaged.
Recording lectures and releasing slides was helpful. Using the raise hand feature was helpful.
I think the teacher did a really good job of teaching virtually, I don't know exactly what could've been improved but I'm sure this class could only get better in person
succeeded: recording lectures plus offering office hours

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Definitely. One of the best CS classes I have taken in Yale.
Absolutely, this is a great class to understand not just the principles of networks, but also engineering and designing good abstractions.
I would recommend to any computer science major as you learn concepts that are applicable to any system as large of a scale as the Internet.

Yes, this course was a fantastic introduction to networking. It is absolutely essential for any computer science student to be familiar with these concepts and they are quite enjoyable to learn. If you want to understand the beautiful way in which our world communicates near instantaneously, you must take this course.

Yes but only if you're an upperclassmen who has had enough experience with CS classes or do not care about your grades. The material is hard and lots of concepts are covered on the exams. This is probably the hardest Yale CS class I've taken other than 323.

I would definitely recommend this course. The internet is the backbone of our modern world and it would be criminal to not get a thorough understanding of how it works as a Computer Science major (especially when the course is so well taught).
Great CS elective that is both engaging and useful. Absolutely recommended if you are interested in how networks are built and function.

Yes! I came into this class wanting to learn about networks, and I actually learned a ton! This class really does give you a really good introduction and foundation on networks, and at the end we walked through examples on how your computer connects to a website (e.g. google.com).

The course was very well taught and you learn a ton about system design by studying networks. My main complaints were that each TA/ULA only had 1 hour of OH per week, which often felt like it wasn't enough given the length of the problem sets. Also, be careful when Cr/D/F this class because some individuals have received D's if their grades are too low.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Both recorded lecture and live virtual lecture.
Recorded lecture
N/A
live virtual lecture and recorded lectures were both available. There were also multiple live virtual office hours every week
Lectures were recorded
